title: South Africa: Prasa's Plans to 'Shrink' Trains
text:
Nigeria: Roadmap for Safe Road Transportation 
This meant Prasa wanted a locomotive that would eventually be 4 140 mm high (not the 4 264 mm as Rapport stated last week, which was the initial height), be lowered even further to 3 965 mm - the maximum roof height for the particular type of train in South Africa. 
But Vossloh Espa√±a said in a letter, of which Rapport has a copy, that it will not be able to adhere to this Prasa request. 
"Although it is not possible to lower the Euro 4000-locomotive to a height of 4 140 mm... it is our understanding that with the actual height and the information at out disposal, the locomotives should be acceptable for operation on South African railway lines." 
Just over a week later Prasa paid over R468m for the first locomotives. 
While Prasa bosses were seemingly pleased that everything was in order, Transnet, on whose railway lines the trains would run, had concerns. 
On 24 March 2015 Transnet Freight Rail (TFR) CEO Caesar Mtetwa wrote to Prasa's chief engineer Daniel Mtimkulu, informing him the Afro 4000 is exceeding the height restriction. 
Prasa in the past week has maintained that the height is in line with accepted standards for overhead power lines, which is not supposed to hang lower than 4.5 metres. 
Although Prasa said in a statement "immediate corrective measures" would be necessary should the power lines be lower than 4.5m, no mention was made of any lines that are indeed hanging lower than 4.5m. 
Prasa boss Lucky Montana also referred to a report by the University of Stellenbosch (US) that said the Afro 4000 will be able to safely operate under 4.5m high power lines. The university however said in a later statement it never confirmed the Afro 4000 would be safe for "all" rail situations. 
But here is the twist in the tale: Rapport has learned that although the lines are supposed be hang no lower than 4.5 metres - as it was in numerous of the tests conducted by Prasa and the US - many of the lines swing as low as 4.22 metres due to poor maintenance. 
In Prasa's own report of February 2014, it pinpoints four places in Gauteng where the lines are as low as 4.22 metres above the railway lines. "The locomotive comes too close to the contact cable, the risk factor for train drivers is high," the internal Prasa document said. 
The accepted safe distance between the roof of the locomotive and the cables should be at least 150mm. 
At the Denver bridge just outside Johannesburg for example, there would be just one centimetre between the roof of the Afro 4000 and the overhead lines. (According to Prasa's own engineer, this poses an "operational electrical risk". 
The engineeie then suggested a "revised design" and that the delivery of the Afro 4000 be delayed. 
Experts said the maintenance on both the Transnet and Prasa railway lines is in such a poor state that overhead power lines will have to be lifted to accommodate the Afro 4000. 
Rapport understands that the low-hanging cables can be lifted, but it is not clear what the cost implications would be. 
Prasa has also in the past week bragged that the train ran safely between Cape Town and Johannesburg for the Cape Town Jazz Festival. 
But a letter sent from Transnet, and seen by Rapport, indicates it was not such a smooth ride after all. 
In an e-mail sent by a Transnet official to about 20 Transnet and Prasa employees at the end of March, Prasa was lambasted for bringing a premier class train on the return trip to Johannesburg after the jazz fest, pulled by the Afro 4000 without the required "YQ authorisation" of Transnet. "No notice was given of such a move [the trip]. Please arrange that the locomotive be removed from the train," the e-mail instructed. 
On June 30 Transnet administrative head Magiel Pretorius issued a notice to Transnet and Prasa, in which he also raised concerns. "Due to the height restrictions on the section between Veertienstrome to Kimberley, the Afro Class locomotive is not authorised to currently run between Veertienstrome and Kimberley," he said. 
* Between 2 and 13 Afro 4000-locomotives delivered to South Africa to date, have in the past week been pulled out of Cape Town by old SA manufactured Class 6E-locomotives for adjustments, according to a Vossloh report. 
* In his response Prasa spokesperson Moffet Mofokeng said: "Prasa will once again provide a detailed factual list proving the allegations that the Afro 4000 exceeds the requirements of the rail industry in South Africa, wrong." 
"We invite all media, also Rapport, to a presentation and trip on the locomotive. We will also prove how Rapport's reporting has changed after its first misleading article, which proves that their intention was malicious and sensational." 
Source: Rapport
